keywords.indexterm: image tasks create a boot from EBS image

context.p: An EBS-backed image (sometimes referred to as a "bfEBS" image) is an image with a root device that is an EBS volume created from an EBS snapshot. An EBS-backed image has a number of advantages, including:

ul.li: Changes to the data on the image persist after instance termination

context.p: You can create an EBS-backed EMI from an existing .img ﬁle or create your own .img ﬁle. One way to create your own .img ﬁle is to use virt-install as described below. If you already have .img file, skip to the Register an EBS-Backed EMI section.
context.note: Use virt-install on a system with the same operating system version and hypervisor as your Node Controller. If you use an image created by virt-install under a different distribution or hypervisor combination, it is likely that it will not install the correct drivers into the ramdisk and the image will not boot on your Node Controller.
context.p: To create an EBS-backed image file:

step.cmd: On the designated host, use the QEMU disk utility to create a disk image. For example:
Use parted to set the disk label:.
Use virt-install to start a new virtual machine installation using the disk image you just created:
Once you have completed the installation, start the virtual machine using virt-manager or other libvirt tool of your choice.
Configure the virtual machine by connecting to it and making the following changes:

substep.cmd: Comment out the HWADDR entry from the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 file. For example:

info.codeblock: DEVICE="eth0" BOOTPROTO="dhcp" #HWADDR="B8:AC:6F:83:1C:45" IPV6INIT="yes" MTU="1500" NM_CONTROLLED="yes" ONBOOT="yes" TYPE="Ethernet" UUID="499c07cc-4a53-408c-87d2-ce0db991648e" PERSISTENT_DHCLIENT=1

substep.cmd: Add the following option to the end of /boot/grub/menu.lst to get a serial console:
Remove the quiet option from the kernel parameters and grub menu splash image in the /boot/grub/menu.lst file.
Add the following line to the /etc/sysconfig/network file to disable the zeroconf route, which can interfere with access to the metadata service:
Edit /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules and remove the entry for the existing NIC.
Copy the Eucalyptus rc.local file from https://github.com/eucalyptus/Eucalyptus-Scripts/blob/master/rc.local.

task.title: Register an EBS-Backed EMI
task.shortdesc: Creating an EBS-backed EMI will require initial assistance from a helper instance. The helper instance can be either an instance store or EBS-backed instance and can be deleted when ﬁnished. It only exists to help create the initial volume that will be the source of the snapshot behind the EBS-backed EMI.

step.cmd: Create and launch a help instance.
Create a volume big enough to hold the bootable .img file.
Attach the volume to the helper instance.
Log in to the instance and copy the bootable image to the attached volume by performing one of the following steps:

choices.choice:
If the bootable image is saved in an http or ftp repository, use curl or wget to download the .img file to the attached volume. For example:
curl <path_to_bootable_image> > <device>

If the bootable image is from a source other than an http or FTP repository, copy the bootable image from its source to the helper instance, and then copy it to the attached volume using the dd command. For example:
dd if=<path_to_bootable_image> of=<device> bs=1M

step.cmd: Detach the volume from the instance:
Create a snapshot of the volume:

taskbody.result: You've now created a EBS-backed image. To maintain data persistence, be sure to use euca-stop-instances and euca-start-instances to stop and start your EBS-backed instance.
